subject: RE: [junit] TestCase question
msgSnippet: Hi All! I just want to thank for all those who replied. cheers Andrea p.s.: I think I can use this multiple failures stuff as well.thanx. ...
messageBody:
Hi All!

I just want to thank for all those who replied.
cheers
Andrea

p.s.: I think I can use this multiple failures stuff as well.thanx.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Shane Celis [mailto:shane@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, October 09, 2001 10:51 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] TestCase question
>
>
> It sounds as though you want multiple failures, but maybe I'm reading
> too much into what you're saying. Take a look at this page
> ( http://www.gnufoo.org/junit/index.html#failures ). The
> paradigm JUnit
> has adopted works very well for unit testing, and I don't see much
> reason to change it, but I don't think it works well for
> every sort of
> testing.
>
> -shane
>
> On Monday, October 8, 2001, at 05:48 AM, Nagy Andrea wrote:
>
> > hi!
> >
> > Sorry, my mistake (thanks Jason for pointing it out) I meant
> > out.size() instead of (out.size(i)).
> > But my question still holds how to generate separately the
> > testresults?
> > Andrea
> >
> >> -----Original Message-----
> >> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
> >> Sent: Friday, October 05, 2001 2:26 PM
> >> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> >> Subject: RE: [junit] TestCase question
> >>
> >>
> >> If out and in are a Collection of outs and ins, this seems
> like a very
> >> simple means of testing indeed.
> >>
> >> The reason I say "if" above is the "out.size(i)" statement in
> >> your for loop.
> >> It's probably just a typo, but I'll play the part of the
> >> dummy and ask if
> >> that was really what you meant. Was that really what you meant? :)
> >>
> >> -jason
> >>
> >>> -----Original Message-----
> >>> From: Nagy Andrea [mailto:andrea.nagy@...]
> >>> Sent: Friday, October 05, 2001 3:31 AM
> >>> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >>> Subject: [junit] TestCase question
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> Hi All!
> >>>
> >>> We are trying to set up JUnit for functional testing in
> >>> our project.
> >>>
> >>> Could you suggest some solutions for the following
> >>> problem or refer
> >>> me to some earlier postings.
> >>>
> >>> I would like to do the following:
> >>> I have a function that I want to call with
> >> different parameters.
> >>> How is it possible to get the result of each
> >> run separately
> >>>
> >>> 1.
> >>> testXX(){
> >>>
> >>> out1=myFunction(in1);
> >>> assertEquals("diff",expectedout1, out1);
> >>> }
> >>> 2.
> >>> And I have a list of theses in1 and expectedout1 things.
> >>>
> >>> how could I combine both these features into a
> >> testcase?
> >>> Does it make sense at all?
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> All I could imagine was the following thing,
> >> but it seems to
> >>> contradict the paradigm to keep your tests simple and small.
> >>>
> >>> testXX(){
> >>> for (i=0;i< out.size(i);i++){
> >>> out[i]=myFunction(in[i]);
> >>>
> >> assertEquals("diff",expectedout[i], out[i]);
> >>> }
> >>> }
> >>>
> >>> Any comments will be much appretiated.
> >>> Nagy Andrea
> >>>
